title: 107_hr2787
content: The Act states that any amendments made shall apply to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. Congress makes findings related to mothers in the workforce, children with disabilities, early intervention services, and special education preschool services under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The General Accounting Office also reports on the supply of infant care and care for special needs children. The purpose of this Act is to increase the supply of quality child care for children with disabilities, who often face limited options due to myths, stereotypes, and lack of staff training. The General Accounting Office highlights the scarcity of infant care, care for special needs children, and care during nonstandard hours, especially in low-income communities. SEC. 3. APPLICATION AND PLAN. Amends Section 658E(c) to include families with children with disabilities. SEC. 4. ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF CHILD CARE. Section 658G (42 U.S.C. 9858e) is amended to include activities for children with disabilities, requiring states to use at least 5 percent of funds for quality child care for children with disabilities. Funds must be used for activities to increase quality child care for children with disabilities, including training for child care providers, state licensing agencies, and parents on collaborating for ADA and IDEA implementation. The curr_chunk discusses collaboration to ensure appropriate implementation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, including technical assistance for child care providers, training on assistive technology, and leadership development. The curr_chunk focuses on training for child care staff in assistive technology, leadership skills for directors, and assistance to child care agencies on ADA and IDEA compliance. It also includes grants for staff recruitment and retention. The curr_chunk discusses grants for recruitment and retention of qualified child care staff, including scholarships for staff to obtain degrees or training in child development and increasing salaries for staff with advanced training. Grants and low-interest loans are provided to public agencies and nonprofit organizations for projects that increase availability of inclusive child care programs, child care for infants, and child care during evenings and weekends. SEC. 5. REPORTS. Amended to include disability status. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. Amends Section 658P to define "child with a disability" and "inclusive child care program."
